title: Firms frustrated over Brexit uncertainty
text:
Getty Images Copyright: Getty Images

An internal UK government memo on the consequences of Boris Johnson's Brexit deal renegotiation singles out the removal of the word "adequate" from the UK-EU Political Declaration to describe mechanisms for enforcing common social, environmental, and labour standards after Brexit.

The word "adequate" appears to have been replaced by the word "appropriate".

It could mean the UK may weaken the scope and strength of what are known as Level Playing Field Commitments (LPF), a crucial element in any future UK-EU trade arrangement.

And one expert says that could have an impact on any EU-UK trade deal post-Brexit.

Adam Jackson, director of Brexit advisory services at Grant Thornton tells Radio Five Live's Wake up to Money: "Regarding our future relationship with the EU in terms of trade... if we lower workers' rights, the significance in terms of a trade deal will mean less chance of zero tariffs, as the EU will see us a lower-cost economy."
description: Businesses wait to see if the EU is to grant a three month extension to the UK's leaving date.
